column3: Ah, you are something like yourself again, said Rose, greeting her with a motherly caress, as they met in the lower hall.

column2: How nice it is to have you at home once more.
column3: How nice it is to have you at home once more.

column2: Thank you, mamma, I am very glad to be here; and I had such a good restful sleep.	Thank you, mamma, I am very glad to be here; and I had such a good restful sleep.

column2: How well you look."
column3: How well you look."

column2: But there, your father is calling to you from the sitting-room."
column3: But there, your father is calling to you from the sitting room."

column2: Elsie hastened to obey the summons, and found him seated at his writing desk.
column3: Elsie hastened to obey the summons, and found him seated at his writing desk.

column2: Come here, daughter, he said, "and tell me if you obeyed orders last night."
column3: Come here, daughter, he said, "and tell me if you obeyed orders last night."

column2: Yes, papa, I did.
column3: Yes, papa, I did.

column2: I am writing a few lines to Aunt Wealthy, to tell her of our safe arrival.	I am writing a few lines to Aunt Wealthy, to tell her of our safe arrival.

column2: Have you any message to send?" and laying down his pen he drew her to his knee.
column3: Have you any message to send?" and laying down his pen he drew her to his knee.

column2: Only my love, papa, and--and that she must not be anxious about me, as she said that she should.	Only my love, papa, and-and that she must not be anxious about me, as she said that she should.
column3: true

column2: That I am very safe and happy in the hands of my heavenly Father--and those of the kind earthly one He has given me," she added in a whisper, putting her arms about his neck, and looking in his face with eyes brimful of filial tenderness and love.
column3: That I am very safe and happy in the hands of my heavenly Father-and those of the kind earthly one He has given me," she added in a whisper, putting her arms about his neck, and looking in his face with eyes brimful of filial tenderness and love.

column2: That is right, my darling, he said, "and you shall never want for love while your father lives.
column3: That is right, my darling, he said, "and you shall never want for love while your father lives.

column2: How it rejoices my heart to see you looking so bright and well this morning."
column3: How it rejoices my heart to see you looking so bright and well this morning."

column2: I feat I have not been yielding you the cheerful obedience I ought, papa, she murmured with tears in her eyes, "but I am resolved to try to do so in future; and have been asking help where I know it is to be obtained."
column3: I feat I have not been yielding you the cheerful obedience I ought, papa, she murmured with tears in her eyes, "but I am resolved to try to do so in future; and have been asking help where I know it is to be obtained."

column2: I have no fault to find with you on that score, my dear child, he said tenderly, "but if you can be cheerful, it will be for your own happiness, as well as ours."
column3: I have no fault to find with you on that score, my dear child, he said tenderly, "but if you can be cheerful, it will be for your own happiness, as well as ours."

column2: She kept her promise faithfully, and had her reward in much real enjoyment of the many pleasures provided for her.
column3: She kept her promise faithfully, and had her reward in much real enjoyment of the many pleasures provided for her.

column2: Mr. and Mrs. Dinsmore were still youthful in their feelings, and joined with great zest in the sports of the young people, going with them in all their excursions, taking an active part in all their pastimes, and contriving so many fresh entertainments, that during those few weeks life seemed like one long gala day.
column3: mr and mrs Dinsmore were still youthful in their feelings, and joined with great zest in the sports of the young people, going with them in all their excursions, taking an active part in all their pastimes, and contriving so many fresh entertainments, that during those few weeks life seemed like one long gala day.

column2: Mr. Travilla was with them most of the time.
column3: mr Travilla was with them most of the time.

column2: He had tarried behind in Philadelphia, as Mr. Dinsmore and his daughter passed through, but followed them to Cape Island a few days later.
column3: He had tarried behind in Philadelphia, as mr Dinsmore and his daughter passed through, but followed them to Cape Island a few days later.

column2: The whole party left the shore about the last of September, the Allisons returning to their city residence, Mr. Travilla to his Southern home, and the Dinsmores travelling through Pennsylvania and New York, from one romantic and picturesque spot to another; finishing up with two or three weeks in Philadelphia, during which Rose and Elsie were much occupied with their fall and winter shopping.
column3: The whole party left the shore about the last of September, the Allisons returning to their city residence, mr Travilla to his Southern home, and the Dinsmores travelling through Pennsylvania and New York, from one romantic and picturesque spot to another; finishing up with two or three weeks in Philadelphia, during which Rose and Elsie were much occupied with their fall and winter shopping.

column2: Mr. Dinsmore took this opportunity to pay another flying visit to his two young brothers.
column3: mr Dinsmore took this opportunity to pay another flying visit to his two young brothers.

column2: He found Arthur nearly recovered, and at once asked a full explanation of the affair of Tom Jackson, alias Bromly Egerton; his designs upon Elsie, and Arthur's participation in them.
column3: He found Arthur nearly recovered, and at once asked a full explanation of the affair of Tom Jackson, alias Bromly Egerton; his designs upon Elsie, and Arthur's participation in them.

column2: I know nothing about it, was the sullen rejoinder.
column3: I know nothing about it, was the sullen rejoinder.

column2: You certainly were acquainted with Tom Jackson, and how, but through you, could he have gained any knowledge of Elsie and her whereabouts?
column3: You certainly were acquainted with Tom Jackson, and how, but through you, could he have gained any knowledge of Elsie and her whereabouts?

column2: I don't deny that I've had some dealings with Jackson, but your Egerton I know nothing of whatever.
column3: I don't deny that I've had some dealings with Jackson, but your Egerton I know nothing of whatever.

column2: You may as well speak the truth, sir; it will be much better for you in the end, said Mr. Dinsmore, sternly, his eyes flashing with indignant anger.
column3: You may as well speak the truth, sir; it will be much better for you in the end, said mr Dinsmore, sternly, his eyes flashing with indignant anger.

column2: And you may as well remember that it isn't Elsie you are dealing with.	And you may as well remember that it isn't Elsie you are dealing with.
column3: true

column2: I'm not afraid of you."
column3: I'm not afraid of you."

column2: Perhaps not, but you may well fear Him who has said, 'a lying tongue is but for a moment.' How do you reconcile such an assertion as you have just made with the fact of your having that letter in your possession?
column3: Perhaps not, but you may well fear Him who has said, 'a lying tongue is but for a moment.' How do you reconcile such an assertion as you have just made with the fact of your having that letter in your possession?

column2: I say it's a cowardly piece of business for you to give the lie to a fellow that hasn't the strength to knock you down for it.
column3: I say it's a cowardly piece of business for you to give the lie to a fellow that hasn't the strength to knock you down for it.

column2: You would hardly attempt that if you were in perfect health, Arthur.
column3: You would hardly attempt that if you were in perfect health, Arthur.

column2: I would.
column3: I would.

column2: You have not answered my question about the letter.	You have not answered my question about the letter.
column3: true

column2: I wrote it myself.
column3: I wrote it myself.

column2: A likely story; it is in a very different hand from yours.
column3: A likely story; it is in a very different hand from yours.

column2: I can adopt that hand on occasion, as I'll prove to your satisfaction.
column3: I can adopt that hand on occasion, as I'll prove to your satisfaction.

column2: He opened his desk, wrote a sentence on a scrap of paper, and handed it to Mr. Dinsmore.
column3: He opened his desk, wrote a sentence on a scrap of paper, and handed it to mr Dinsmore.

column2: The chirography was precisely that of the letter. While slowly convalescing, Arthur had prepared for this expected interview with Horace, by spending many a solitary hour in laboriously teaching himself to imitate Jackson's ordinary hand, in which most of the letters he had received from him were written.
column3: The chirography was precisely that of the letter. While slowly convalescing, Arthur had prepared for this expected interview with Horace, by spending many a solitary hour in laboriously teaching himself to imitate Jackson's ordinary hand, in which most of the letters he had received from him were written.

column2: The sentence he had first penned was, "I did it merely for my own amusement, and to hoax Wal."
column3: The sentence he had first penned was, "I did it merely for my own amusement, and to hoax Wal."

column2: I don't believe a word of it, said Mr. Dinsmore, looking sternly at him.
column3: I don't believe a word of it, said mr Dinsmore, looking sternly at him.

column2: Arthur, you had better be frank and open with me.	Arthur, you had better be frank and open with me.
column3: true

column2: You will gain nothing by denying the hand you have had in this disgraceful business. You can hardly suppose me credulous enough to believe an assertion so perfectly absurd as this.
column3: You will gain nothing by denying the hand you have had in this disgraceful business. You can hardly suppose me credulous enough to believe an assertion so perfectly absurd as this.

column2: I have no doubt that you sent that villain to Lansdale to try his arts upon Elsie; and for that you are richly deserving of my anger, and of any punishment it might be in my power to deal out to you.
column3: I have no doubt that you sent that villain to Lansdale to try his arts upon Elsie; and for that you are richly deserving of my anger, and of any punishment it might be in my power to deal out to you.

column2: It has been no easy matter for me to forgive the suffering you have caused my child, Arthur; but I came here to-day with kind feelings and intentions.	It has been no easy matter for me to forgive the suffering you have caused my child, Arthur; but I came here to day with kind feelings and intentions.
column3: true

column2: I hoped to find you penitent and ready to forsake your evil courses; and in that case, intended to help you to pay off your debts and begin anew, without paining father with the knowledge that his confidence in you has been again so shamefully abused.
column3: I hoped to find you penitent and ready to forsake your evil courses; and in that case, intended to help you to pay off your debts and begin anew, without paining father with the knowledge that his confidence in you has been again so shamefully abused.

column2: But I must say that your persistent denial of your complicity with that scoundrel Jackson does not look much like contrition, or intended amendment."
column3: But I must say that your persistent denial of your complicity with that scoundrel Jackson does not look much like contrition, or intended amendment."

column2: Arthur listened in sullen silence, though his rapidly changing color showed that he felt the cutting rebuke keenly.
column3: Arthur listened in sullen silence, though his rapidly changing color showed that he felt the cutting rebuke keenly.

column2: At one time he had resolved to confess everything, throw himself upon the mercy of his father and brother, and begin to lead an honest, upright life; but a threatening letter received that morning from Jackson had led him to change his purpose, and determine to close his lips for a time.
column3: At one time he had resolved to confess everything, throw himself upon the mercy of his father and brother, and begin to lead an honest, upright life; but a threatening letter received that morning from Jackson had led him to change his purpose, and determine to close his lips for a time.

column2: Walter looked at Arthur in surprise.

column2: Come, Art, speak, why don't you? he said.
column3: Come, Art, speak, why don't you? he said.

column2: Horace, don't look so stern and angry, I know he means to turn over a new leaf; for he told me so.	Horace, don't look so stern and angry, I know he means to turn over a new leaf; for he told me so.

column2: And you will help him, won't you?"
column3: And you will help him, won't you?"

column2: I ask no favors from a man who throws the lie in my teeth, muttered Arthur angrily.
column3: I ask no favors from a man who throws the lie in my teeth, muttered Arthur angrily.

column2: And I can give none to one who persists in denying his guilt, replied Mr. Dinsmore.
column3: And I can give none to one who persists in denying his guilt, replied mr Dinsmore.

column2: But, Arthur, I give you one more chance, and for our father's sake I hope you will avail yourself of it.	But, Arthur, I give you one more chance, and for our father's sake I hope you will avail yourself of it.

column2: If you go on as you have for the last three or four years, you will bring down his gray hairs with sorrow to the grave.

column2: I presume you have put yourself in Jackson's power; but if you will now make a full and free confession to me, and promise amendment, I will help you to get rid of the rascal's claims upon you, and start afresh.
column3: I presume you have put yourself in Jackson's power; but if you will now make a full and free confession to me, and promise amendment, I will help you to get rid of the rascal's claims upon you, and start afresh.

column2: Will you do it?"
